results.title: Drink no Longer Water
results.creator_credit: Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation and Fontana Films
results.brief_description: A humourous romp through various wine styles set in the country in a castle-like structure. Vignettes played out by actors - some in period costume to emulate the character of various wine varieties/styles from Moselle “for first lovers” through to claret are you old enough? Featuring Australian actors Steve Bisley and Mel Gibson in their youth.

results.title: The Heritage of the uncommon man
results.creator_credit: Reid H Ray and BNA Communications
results.brief_description: Joe Powell, a noted lecturer to businessmen, expounds his notions of the “Uncommon man” - the man who gets results. In an entertaining lecture, Powell describes the attributes and behaviour of the successful executive. Uses cartoons to illustrate some points of the lecture.

results.title: People (Yallourn's Royal Hour 1954; Born to Die; Sir John Monash)

video_links.name: People (Yallourn's Royal Hour 1954; Born to Die; Sir John Monash)

results.brief_description: “Yallourn’s Royal Hour” highlights the visit to Yallourn of Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh on 3rd March 1954. Film of the royal motorcade through Melbourne is shown before their arrival in Yallourn where they inspect the coal extraction site at Yallourn Cut (16 min). “Born to Die” focuses on the prospect that Yallourn will be demolished to enable access to the coal reserves beneath it. Includes comments by the townspeople on their feelings about this. (48 mins) “Sir John Monash” is a tribute to the life of this pioneer Australian. The Vice Chancellor of Monash University speaks on his life and an account of his achievements is given. (27 min)

results.title: Looking at plants
results.creator_credit: Jim Harris, John Bird and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Filmed in the Sherbrooke Forest Park, Australflora Nursery, Victoria, and shows glimpses of the plant and insect life which abound there. No narration, music only.

results.title: [Black Knight]
results.brief_description: A survey of the development of the British “Black Knight” rocket test vehicle and its use in high speed flight and ballistic missile research. The elements of construction, ground support equipment, propulsion, guidance and instrumentation are discussed. Tests and launching preparations at Australia’s Woomera Range follow, closing with a night-firing sequence. NB: No opening or closing credits

results.title: Service to the inland
results.creator_credit: J. Campbell Dobbie and Peerless Films
results.brief_description: A story of the inland telegraph, demonstrating the need for and efficiency of the inland communications system. Shows a message from a Northern Territory bush wireless to Dunlop Tyres translated into a narrative about developments in the outback (transportation, primary industry, the flying doctor etc.). Also includes footage of Aboriginal couriers travelling overland on foot, Aboriginal settlements, their culture, cooking, food gathering etc, in particular Emily’s Gap.

results.title: A Record of pre-school play
results.creator_credit: Australian Council for Educational Research and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: These children are representative of 100 who commenced primary school in Carlton during 1951. Some children had attended the Lady Gowrie Pre-School Centre, some came from other kindergartens and creches and some had not attended any pre-school centre. The children were assembled for two weeks at the end of 1950 to study their vocabulary and this film was made of their unrehearsed and undirected activities. Photography by Rodney Power.

results.title: Apollo 10: around the moon
results.creator_credit: United States. National Aeronautics Space Administration
results.brief_description: The film shows various footage of Apollo 10’s travel around the moon including: the Command module filmed from the Lunar module; the far side of the moon; Command module over landing site No. 2; view from Lunar module sixty miles up; inside the Lunar module; Lunar module descent and much more.
